Award.AwardTitle: Theory and Methods for Estimation of Nonsmooth Functionals and Detection of Simultaneous Signals
Award.AbstractNarration:
The collection and analysis of high dimensional data is now of central importance in a wide range of scientific applications, including genomics, bioinformatics, climate studies, and signal processing. There are many new challenges in the analysis of such high dimensional data and there is much demand for the development of new statistical theory and methodology in this field. Although high dimensional data is often analyzed using complex models in many applications, attention is often focused on testing specific hypotheses that are of low dimension. In such cases new statistical theory and methodology relies on the development of new techniques for estimating non-smooth functionals, the topic of this project.

The focus of this research project is to establish a comprehensive methodology for estimating non-smooth functionals and to show how this methodology can be used in the detection and testing of multiple high-dimensional sparse sequences encountered in genomics. The proposed research will provide scientists with new methodologies to analyze such highly complex data. The statistical procedures developed in this project will be implemented in a high-level programming language and made available on the internet with the related research reports so as to allow comparisons with other approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Theory and Methods for Estimation of Nonsmooth Functionals and Detection of Simultaneous Signals


Tony Cai has been supported by DMS-1403708 “Theory and Methods for Estimation of Nonsmooth Functionals and Detection of Simultaneous Signals” ($485,840) from 09/01/2014 to 08/30/2017. Over these 3 years, the PI has been working on a range of problems concerning the theoretical and methodological aspects of big data.  He led a research group of Ph.D. students, postdocs, and collaborators on developing theories and methodologies for high-dimensional statistics and applications in genomics. 


Major Outcomes and Activities:
1. Published over 40 journal papers during the period, including more than 20 papers in leading statistics journals such as the Annals of Statistics, Journal of the American Statistical Association, Journal of the Royal Statistical Society (Series B), and Biometrika. The newly proposed procedures were implemented in R and/or Matlab. All the papers and software were made freely available on his website.
2. Developed detection methods for detecting simultaneous signals as well as unique signals; Developed adaptive procedures and established optimal rates for sparse PCA; Developed statistical methods for large-scale inference; Developed optimality theory for statistical inference for high-dimensional linear models. Addressed a range of applications in medical research, including identifying gene regulatory networks with gene expression data and identifying genetically controlled disease genes. 
3. Presented 36 colloquium talks, 15 invited talks and 19 plenary/distinguished lectures at scientific conferences, including the Special Invited Lecture at the 6th IMS-China Conference in July 2017; The Annals of Statistics Editors’ special invited talk at the Joint Statistical Meetings in August 2015, and the Plenary Lecture at the International Conference on Robust Statistics in Kolkata, India in January 2015.
4. Co-organized several international conferences on topics directly related to research supported by the NSF grants, including “2016 International Conference on Data Science" in Shanghai in December 2016; and the 2017 IMS Annual Meeting at the Joint Statistical Meetings in Baltimore in August 2017.


These conferences brought together statisticians, engineers, and medical researchers to advance the theory, methodology and applications of high-dimensional inference. They also provided opportunities for scholars from diverse disciplines to interact and strengthen each other's knowledge and expertise in analyzing high-dimensional data to yield maximal new knowledge toward the establishment of rigorous statistical and biological foundations for the better understanding of health and disease. 

Intellectual Merit: 
Under the support of this NSF grant, Tony Cai developed new statistical methods for a range of large-scale inference problems, including detection of simultaneous signals and unique signals, large-scale multiple testing, network data analysis, and high-dimensional linear regression.  These results advanced the theoretical understanding and methodological development for high-dimensional statistics and analysis of Big Data. In addition, he addressed a range of applications in medical research, including identifying gene regulatory networks with gene expression data and identifying genetically controlled disease genes. 


Broader Impacts:  
The results developed by Tony Cai have a great impact in the broad scientific community. They provide theory, methodology, applications, as well as technical tools to researchers in other scientific fields who collect and analyze high-dimensional data sets. These fields include astronomy, biology, chemistry, bioinformatics, as well as various clinical research areas in general. In the last four years, Tony Cai trained (and is training) 8 postdocs and 9 Ph.D. students, including 3 female postdocs and 1 female student, all of whom have taken up faculty positions at research universities. To disseminate the newly obtained results, he taught advanced topics courses on high dimensional statistical inference and nonparametric inference to Ph.D. students and postdocs at Penn. He also gave public lectures on big data at other institutions. All the papers and implementations of the procedures in R/Matlab were available online.
